p: Similar to the HBV infection, HCV-infected individuals can eliminate the virus naturally or develop chronic infection, which occurs in 55–85 % of the cases. Chronic infection can cause liver inflammation, cirrhosis, and hepatocarcinoma ( Lingala and Ghany, 2015). In addition to liver damage, HCV causes a series of immune-mediated extrahepatic manifestations, including rheumatologic, dermatologic, ophthalmologic, renal, pulmonary, neuropsychiatric, cardiovascular, and hematologic manifestations, especially mixed cryoglobulinemia ( Romano et al., 2018). HCV therapy using direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) shows cure rates over 95 % ( Pietschmann and Brown, 2019). Early treatment of infected patients decreases death rates from HCV-associated liver disease, reduces disease transmission, and alleviates extrahepatic health problems. Focusing the efforts on HCV treatment is extremely important because there is no effective HCV vaccine ( Viganò et al., 2019).
